Becomes the greatest newspaper tycoon of his generation, widely recognized and influential in journalism and publishing.
Elicits passionately conflicting opinions about his character and actions, indicating controversial or contradictory behavior.

For forty years appeared in Kane newsprint no public issue on which Kane papers took no stand.
No public man whom Kane himself did not support or denounce - often support, then denounce.

In a silent rage, destroys Susan's room with tremendous speed and surprising strength, methodically tearing it apart.
Stops abruptly after the destructive outburst, notices the snow globe but awkwardly fails to pick it up himself, needing Raymond's help.
Gently shakes the glass snowball and is almost in a trance, quietly instructs Raymond to lock the door and keep it locked, speaks so softly it seems he is talking to himself.
Passes quietly through servants who watch him silently as he leaves.
Stands silently near the burial of his son, watching the workmen lower the coffin.
Engages Raymond in a personal conversation about poetry and past memories, trying to share meaning and reflection.
Appears distant and detached, looking through people and things rather than fully engaging.
Ignores practical concerns of the workmen and Raymond, appearing detached and lost in poetic and symbolic thoughts.
Recalls and quotes poetry with some insight, showing an intellectual side despite his frailty.
Demonstrates confusion about his relationships and surroundings, indicating a decline in mental acuity.
Engages thoughtfully with his butler Raymond, revealing some awareness and emotional depth despite confusion.
Calls tributary kings together and offers them hills of gold and mountains of silver, seeking only one more day upon earth.
Stares silently and emotionally distant, showing isolation and alienation as others remain silent and do not respond to his offerings.
Quotes a reflective, poetic monologue about power, mortality, and the futility of worldly wealth with calmness and depth.
Stares blankly through the wall and beyond it, indicating detachment from reality or inability to act effectively in his final moments.
Shows vulnerability and loss of control in his last years, described as 'a little gone in the head' and needing others to 'handle him.'
He went right on buying - right up to the end.
Collects a vast array of items, apparently indiscriminately ('anything and everything - he was a regular crow').
He was a liberal and a reactionary; he was tolerant - 'Live and Let Live' - that was his motto.
He had no use for anybody who disagreed with him on any point, no matter how small it was.
He was a loving husband and a good father - and both his wives left him and his son got himself killed about as shabbily as you can do it.
He had a gift for friendship such as few men have - he broke his oldest friend's heart like you'd throw away a cigarette you were through with.
Got everything he wanted, showing ability to achieve goals.
Had no use for anybody who disagreed with him on any point, showing intolerance and inflexibility.
Broke his oldest friend's heart like throwing away a cigarette, showing poor interpersonal skills.
Lost everything he had achieved, indicating failure to maintain success.
